DOC.HEAD: Indian Publisher Returns H.L. Mencken Award In Wake of Racist Comments
DOC.TEXT: The Sioux publisher of the Lakota Times said Friday he has returned the H.L. Mencken Writing Award he won in 1985 because of racist and sexist remarks Mencken made in his recently published diaries. ``I feel very strongly that everything that I have fought for in the last 20 years to try and improve race relations ... it just wouldn't wash if I accepted an award and kept an award from a person that has attitudes that are so bigoted.'' said Tim Giago, a member of the Oglala Sioux tribe. His weekly paper is named for the dominant Sioux language. ``I have a strong feeling that this kind of subtle racism, by people that are in a position to help, is probably the worst form of racism. ``We can deal with outright, blatant, redneck racism because it's right there in front of us,'' he said. ``But it is very hard to deal with that kind of racism by people in prominent positions, especially in the media, that carry this silent racial attitude with them.'' Giago, of Rapid City, said he also will return the $2,500 prize that came with the award. Mencken, the famous columnist for The Sun of Baltimore, wrote his diaries between 1930 and 1948. Publication was withheld until more than 25 years after his death in 1956. Giago writes a weekly syndicated column on Indian issues for 20 newspapers across the country. He said he doubted others who attended the ceremony with him five years ago, such as Coretta Scott King, the wife of slain civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr., would have taken part if they had known about Mencken's attitudes toward blacks, women and Jews. In one entry, Mencken wrote: ``It is impossible to talk anything resembling discretion or judgment to a colored woman. They are all essentially child-like and even hard experience does not teach them anything.'' A spokesman for the Baltimore Sun, which sponsors the award, said Friday neither Publisher Reg Murphy nor other senior management at the newspaper were available for comment. Murphy wrote in Editor and Publisher recently that he had considered ending the awards because of the diaries, but decided against it. ``You don't throw away all of the wonderful work of a man like Mencken that was in the public domain because of the private venom,'' he wrote in the trade magazine. Another Mencken award recipient, Chicago Tribune columnist Mike Royko, told the Sioux Falls Argus Leader he does not plan to return his award because of Mencken's private thoughts.
